Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Central Anatolian Tectonics (CD-CAT): Surface to mantle dynamics during collision to escape
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an integrated program to study the process of tectonic escape in Central Anatolia. This is the location where this process was first recognized in the 1970s and the PIs make a strong case that this is good place to investigate the temporal and spatial characteristics of this process in the context of a continent-continent collision.

The research builds on previous geophysical and geological studies by many of the PIs in other parts of Turkey (both to the east and west of the planned study area). The research will investigate modern structure through a combination of geophysics and geology. Past history will be reconstructed through studies of elevation, drainage and volcanism. Studies of the Central Anatolian fault are important as this is a major feature that is poorly understood in Anatolian tectonics.

Specifically, the PIs will address the questions:

? What are the plate dynamics from the mantle to the Earth?s surface, the transition from distributed to localized strain in large strike-slip faults, the origin and consequences of magmatism, and the evolution of relief and landscape during development of escape tectonics?
? What are the effects of boundary conditions (collision of Arabian plate to the east, extension of Aegean to the west, subduction of African plate to the south) on the driving forces of tectonic escape?

The study will integrate results of passive seismic experiments; magnetotelluric profiling; geomorphic, structural, and stratigraphic-sedimentological analysis of surface geology and exhumed orogenic crust; geo/thermochronometric determination of temperature-time histories of magmatic, metamorphic, and fault zone rocks and geomorphic features; isotopic fingerprinting and dating of magmatic rocks; and 2D and 3D numerical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Anatolian tectonic plate is currently moving west toward the Aegean region at approximately 2 cm/year, pulled by extension in the west and pushed by compression in the east. The tectonic plate is bounded by the earthquake-generating North and East Anatolian Faults, which allow Anatolia to slide westward. These major faults formed < 10 million years ago, although the driving forces of the westward ?tectonic escape? of Anatolia have been active for more than 25 million years. In this project, an interdisciplinary team of researchers from the US, Turkey, Canada, Germany, and Australia investigated the geologic record of Anatolia to understand the mechanisms and timing of tectonic transitions, including identifying the timing and extent of inception of tectonic escape. In particular, the research led by the University of Minnesota (UMN) documented changes in fault zones, surface processes such as lake and river systems, topographic features such as mountain ranges, and the exposure of formerly-deep rocks (metamorphic, igneous) by faulting and erosion. A particular focus of the UMN team was the region in the vicinity of the Central Anatolian Fault Zone, a major strike-slip fault with a long (>90 million year) history. Results from this research were integrated with other parts of the CD-CAT project, including information from the geophysics, magmatic, and basin studies components.

Collision of Arabia with Eurasia created a broad zone of deformation in which major faults formed -- many at old boundaries related to previous tectonic events. We identified a phase of pre-escape tectonics that endured for nearly 20 million years, driven by the oblique push of the Arabian plate and the pull of the Aegean extension zone; this eventually created the North Anatolian Fault. The western boundary of the broad zone of deformation is the Central Anatolian Fault Zone. On either side of this fault, sediments in basins have completely different sources and thermal histories, and volcanic rocks have different sources (melting conditions) and ages. We tracked the evolution of sedimentary sources and changes in the surface (topography, river systems) using the geochemistry of distinctive rock types, ages of sediments and bedrock exposures, and analysis of structural features such as faults.

A change from deposition to erosion occurred very rapidly across Central Anatolia about 5 million years ago. Lake deposits cut by rivers show that major changes occurred in the river systems across Central Anatolia, driven by the faults that formed as the tectonic escape system developed, particularly between 5 and 3 million years ago.  

The current system of tectonic escape developed with the inception of the East Anatolian Fault as a through-going structure about 3 million years ago. The change from pre-escape to full-escape is tracked in the history of magmatism and uplift. We obtained new ages for volcanic rocks, and coupled these ages with data and interpretations from CD-CAT geophysical data and historical information from faults and basins to understand the most recent phase of the tectonic history of the region.

Another, related aim of the project was to determine the location and behavior of an oceanic tectonic plate that is today below parts of Anatolia: it has been imaged with seismic waves below western Anatolia and has been shown to be absent below eastern Anatolia, leaving the question of where the eastern edge of the plate is, and what the consequences of the sinking and tearing of this plate have been for the Anatolian crust and surface.

Integrated results of this project showed that the edge of the sunken and torn plate is marked at the surface by the Central Anatolian Fault Zone, a region of high topography (eastern Taurus Mountains), and volcanism focused in and near the fault zone. The rise of the Taurus Mts was tracked through time in records of how climate changed in Central Anatolia. Prior to the rise of the mountains, the climate was less arid. Once the mountains attained their current elevation about 5 million years ago, aridity increased. The record of this climate change linked to rise of the mountains is in the composition and age of sequences of lake sediments deposited over the past 20+ million years across Central Anatolia.

In total, considering the US institutions and international partners, 23 graduate degrees resulted from the CD-CAT project (13 MS, 10 PhD), including three at UMN. The UMN part of the project also supported two postdoctoral researchers. The research has resulted in a themed issue of the journal Geosphere, and additional publications in other journals. International cooperation in research was integral to this project, the results of which have implications for understanding seismic and volcanic hazards in Central Anatolia.
